column1: Ancient Egyptians used pictures to make a phonetic alphabet as in a rebus
column2: so that each sound could be written with a picture-word
column3: a phonogram or pictograph. For example
column4: a zig-zag for water came to mean the letter "n"
column5: because the Egyptian word for water started with n. This same picture became our letter 'M' in the Latin alphabet
column6: because the Semitic word for water started with m
column7: and Semitic workers changed the symbols to fit sounds in their own language. In the same way
column8: our Latin letter 'N' came from the hieroglyph for snake as the word for "snake" started with n in Semitic. In Egyptian
column9: this picture had stood for a sound like English "J" because of their word for snake. Some pictures came to represent ideas
column10: and these are known as ideograms.The Egyptians used between 700 or 800 pictures
column11: or glyphs. They were written from right to left and from top to bottom. They did not use punctuation.
